issues.title: Is "CMS KEMRecipientInfo Processing Summary" section needed?
issues.author: danvangeest
issues.body:
Section 1.4 "CMS KEMRecipientInfo Processing Summary" was copied from rfc5990bis.  Section 2 in cms-kemri is a more complete statement of the process, so is our section needed?

If we keep it, in the AuthenticatedData case the key that is transfered is a MAC key, not a CEK.

comments.author: danvangeest
comments.body: Russ: rfc5990bis is in WGLC and nobody has shouted about section 1.4 so hopefully it's okay.

issues.title: KMAC KDF OIDs
issues.author: danvangeest
issues.body:
We should be getting KMAC-based KDF OIDs, either from NIST or LAMPS.  Switch to those.

If we don't get them, is it better to specify HKDF-with-SHA3, or KDF3-with-SHA3 as MTI?

comments.author: danvangeest
comments.body: Done in -03

issues.title: Harmonize security considerations
issues.author: danvangeest
issues.body: Harmonize Security Considerations section between this and draft-ietf-lamps-kyber-certificates.

comments.author: seanturner
comments.body: Agreed. I went for the refer to [draft-sfluhrer-cfrg-ml-kem-security-considerations](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-sfluhrer-cfrg-ml-kem-security-considerations/), but that might be overkill. At a minimum, it adds a dependency. Also, not sure how the IESG will react to an informative reference for all of the security considerations.

issues.title: Add examples
issues.author: danvangeest
issues.body:
See Appendices C and D of https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-lamps-rfc5990bis/ for examples.

We probably don't need a SMIMECapabilities Examples section because our encoding is much simpler that for RSA-KEM.

comments.author: danvangeest
comments.body: Done with #14

issues.title: Is "CMS KEMRecipientInfo Processing Summary" needed?
issues.author: danvangeest
issues.body:
Is the "CMS KEMRecipientInfo Processing Summary" section needed? Both Mike and Carl pointed this out during review.  It is basically a less complete version of section 2 from cms-kemri.

I added the section because rfc5990bis also has this section.  I will see if Russ wants to remove it from rfc5990bis or if there's justification to keep it there (and here).

comments.author: danvangeest
comments.body: Duplicate of #2

issues.title: KMAC OR HKDF-with-SHA2-*
issues.author: danvangeest
issues.body:
KMAC uses SHAKE (SHA3).  HKDF-with-SHA2-* uses SHA2.

Currently the draft specifies KMAC as the only MTI KDF algorithm.  There was a concern from LAMPS (Deb Cooley) that some implementations might not have access to SHA3/KMAC at the CMS level.  That is, SHA3 may only be at the crypto level (maybe even in an HSM or TPM) since ML-KEM requires it, but many other things don't.  On the other hand, low-resource devices may want to only support SHA3 and not SHA2.

It was mentioned in LAMPS IETF 119 that we could give the option for either to be supported, with good reasoning to it doesn't get challenged by IESG.

Suggested text, before I have time to actually write a PR:

```
One of KMAC{128,256} or HKDF-with-SHA{256,512} MUST be supported.  It is RECOMMENDED that both be supported.
```

and then specific details for each of the security variants.

issues.title: ASN.1
issues.author: danvangeest
issues.body:
Add ASN.1 with SMIMECaps. See composite-kems CMS section and ASN.1.

Someone needs to define a KEM-ALGORITHM for ML-KEM, I think it should be the kyber-certificates, but tracking it here just in case.

issues.title: More KMAC vs HKDF
issues.author: danvangeest
issues.body: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-lamps-cms-cek-hkdf-sha256/ requires HKDF-with-SHA256 for its mitigation.  Are there any use cases where this mitigation wouldn't be implemented?  If not, this essentially means that HKDF and SHA2 is required in CMS.  Does this mean that cms-kyber should just switch its MTI KDF to only HKDF and remove the requirement for KMAC?

comments.author: danvangeest
comments.body: done with #14

issues.title: ML-KEM description in abstract
issues.author: danvangeest
issues.body:
Deirdre pinged me privately to complain about the abstract:


“The Module-Lattice-based Key-Encapsulation Mechanism (ML-KEM)
   algorithm is a one-pass (store-and-forward) cryptographic mechanism
   for an originator to securely send keying material to a recipient
   using the recipient's ML-KEM public key.

I agree that when combined with CMS and KEMRI, you get a one-pass store-and-forward construct – IE the encrypted CMS payload and all the crypto stuff go together in the same message. But ML-KEM by itself is not a store-and-forward; it’s a KEM.

I suggest instead just borrowing the abstract off draft-ietf-lamps-kyber-certificates:

“Module-Lattice-Based Key-Encapsulation Mechanism (ML-KEM) is a
   quantum-resistant key-encapsulation mechanism (KEM).  This document
   specifies conventions for using ML-KEM within the Cryptographic Message Syntax (CMS).

issues.title: Check examples
issues.author: seanturner
issues.body: While doing the examples, see [here](https://github.com/lamps-wg/kyber-certificates/pull/58/files) and [here](https://github.com/lamps-wg/kyber-certificates/pull/61), I noticed that they private key in this I-D seems to be lot bigger than the certificates examples.  Is the private key here just the seed?

comments.author: danvangeest
comments.body: You are right.  I made these examples before kyber-certificates specified use of the seed,  In fact, my crypto library developer has pushed back against using the private key seed, so when kyber-certificates is updated I'll have something to show him to prove it's a requirement.

comments.author: danvangeest
comments.body: Fixed in #21

issues.title: Make draft private-key-format agnostic
issues.author: danvangeest
issues.body: With the disagreements going on about private key format for ML-KEM, can we make this draft format agnostic?  I think the only places where this would apply is that we currently refer to ML-KEM.KeyGen() and ML-KEM.Decaps() from FIPS 203.  These functions explicitly use the expanded key.

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body: Thanks for the work on this Dan!

```suggestion
Native support for Key Encapsulation Mechanisms (KEMs) was added to CMS in {{!I-D.ietf-lamps-cms-kemri}}, which defines the KEMRecipientInfo structure for the use of KEM algorithms for the CMS enveloped-data content type, the CMS authenticated-data content type, and the CMS authenticated-enveloped-data content type. This document specifies the use of ML-KEM in the KEMRecipientInfo structure in CMS at three security levels: MK-KEM-512, ML-KEM-768, ML-KEM-1024.
```

```suggestion
The main security property for KEMs standardized in the NIST Post-Quantum Cryptography Standardization Project {{NIST-PQ}} is indistinguishability under adaptive chosen ciphertext attacks (IND-CCA2), which means that shared secret values should be indistinguishable from random strings even given the ability to have arbitrary ciphertexts decapsulated. IND-CCA2 corresponds to security against an active attacker, and the public key / secret key pair can be treated as a long-term key or reused. A weaker security notion is indistinguishability under chosen plaintext attacks (IND-CPA), which means that the shared secret values should be indistinguishable from random strings given a copy of the public key. IND-CPA roughly corresponds to security against a passive attacker, and sometimes corresponds to one-time key exchange.

IND-CCA2 is a desirable property of encryption mechanisms for CMS since encryption public keys are often long-term -- for example contained within X.509 certificates {{?RFC5280}} -- and certain uses of CMS could allow for the type of decryption oracle that forms the basis of an adaptive ciphertext attack.
```

```suggestion
ML-KEM is a lattice-based key encapsulation mechanism defined in {{FIPS203}}.
```
"recently standardized" will not stand the test of time :)

```suggestion
1\. Obtain the shared secret and ciphertext using the Encapsulate() function of the ML-KEM algorithm and the recipient's ML-KEM public key:
```

I find this section confusing because it is conceptually crossing the boundaries of the processing done in this document and in the KEMRI document.

I think I would remove this section in its entirety so that casual readers don't think that ML-KEM needs to include a KDF and a WRAP.
This is odd to be so low in the document. Usually the boilerplate is section 1.1.
Yup! I agree with this ednote; this section will be in flux (and I will need to align draft-composite-kem with whatever choice is made here).

```suggestion

None.

```

```suggestion

[ednote: many of the security considerations below apply to ML-KEM in general and are not specific to ML-KEM within CMS. As this document and draft-ietf-lamps-kyber-certificates approach WGLC, the two Security Consideration sections should be harmonized and duplicate text removed.]

```
This paragraph was stolen from draft-kampanakis-ml-kem-ikev2, so if that gets adopted we'll have to make the same comment there :)

@ounsworth, this was stolen directly from section 1.3 of rfc5990bis, does the same comment apply there? :) https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-lamps-rfc5990bis-04.html#name-cms-kemrecipientinfo-proces

There is useful normative language in here:
- CMS originator MUST implement Encapsulate()
- CMS recipient MUST implement Decapsulate()
- KDF MAY be different than the internal ML-KEM one.
Although the first two may be obvious and the third may be more important for rfc5990bis because that document also describes the RSA-KEM process.

If we kept this text, would it be more clear if at the beginning it made clear that these are the same steps from cms-kemri?  Or do you still think it's better to just remove it?
Also copied from rfc5990bis, but I can move it up.
BTW I heard directly from Russ that we'll get OIDs for KMAC-based KDFs.  If NIST doesn't assign them as he asked then LAMPS will.

Ugg, yeah, that really is copied directly from the KEMRecipientInfo section of 5990bis. 
Ugg, ok, fine then.

pulls.title: Jonathan Hammell's review and ASN.1 module.
pulls.author: danvangeest

reviews.author: ounsworth
reviews.body:
Hey Dan,

Thank you again for your work on this!

First off, the CMS-KYBER-2024.asn looks incomplete. To my eye, I see that things like id-alg-ml-kem-512 and pk-ml-kem-512 are used but not defined nor imported. And when I try to compile it in ASN.1 playground, I get errors that '&smimeCaps' is not defined for the object 'kema-ml-kem-512'. So I think the ASN.1 module needs some work.


> “A compliant implementation MUST support HKDF with SHA-256, using the id-alg-hkdf-with-sha256 KDF object identifier, as the KemRecipientInfo KDF for all ML-KEM parameter sets.”

Perfect! Simple. That nails it.

Once the ASN.1 module compiles and is complete, I agree that this is ready for WGLC.

pulls.title: Address Secdir review
pulls.author: danvangeest
pulls.body:
Addressing SECDIR review from Yaron Sheffer.

https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/review-ietf-lamps-cms-kyber-10-secdir-lc-sheffer-2025-06-23/

comments.author: ounsworth
comments.body:
Suggestion for comments back to Yaron:

> SECDIR comment: An editorial question: you "deep link" to specific algorithm numbers in FIPS 203.  Is this legit? Can FIPS publish a new version of the document and mix up
the numbers?

> Authors response: This is a fair question to ask the RFC Editor, but our document is consistent with draft-ietf-lamps-kyber-certificates-10 which has, for example:
> "To support serialization of seed values as private keys, let Algorithm 19b denote the same procedure as Algorithm 19 in [[FIPS203](https://doi.org/10.6028/nist.fips.203)]"
> I thin this is ok because there will only ever be one document called "FIPS.203". If NIST publishes updates, they will name that "FIPS.203a".

> SECDIR comment: 2.1: "ukm" sounds like a useless piece of complexity - even some complexity if
you don't implement it. Given that this is a profile of [RFC 9629](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc9629/), couldn't you
remove it?

> Authors response: "Useless" is a bit strong. This provides a way for the application to bind extra context information or out-of-band pre-shared key material. I think we should leave it exposed.


> SECDIR comment: 2.3, as far as I can tell, you are more strict than [RFC 9629](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc9629/) in saying that
only keyEncipherment must be asserted.

> Authors response: The issue here is that there exists `keyEncipherment` which usually indicates an RSA Key Transport mechanism, and `keyAgreement` which usually indicates a Diffie-Hellman style key agreement. A KEM does not fit cleanly into either. LAMPS had a big debate about this several years ago and decided that by convention, all KEMs will use the `keyEncipherment` key usage. This is the only key usage allowed for ML-KEM as per draft-ietf-lamps-kyber-certificates.

```suggestion
The Module Lattice Key Encapsulation Mechanism (ML-KEM) is an IND-CCA2-secure key-encapsulation mechanism (KEM) standardized in {{FIPS203}} by the US NIST PQC Project {{NIST-PQ}}. ML-KEM is the name given to the final standardized version and is incompatible with pre-standards versions, often called "Kyber".
```

pulls.title: Expand randomness text but remove RFC 4086 reference
pulls.author: danvangeest

reviews.author: ounsworth
reviews.body: I'm ok with this as-is, but I put a suggestion with further word-smithing.

comments.body:
```suggestion
The generation of private keys relies on random numbers, as does the encapsulation function of ML-KEM.  The use of inadequate pseudo-random number generators (PRNGs) to generate these values can result in little or no security.  In the case of key generation, a random 32-byte seed is used to deterministically derive the key (with an additional 32 bytes reserved as a rejection value). In the case of encapsulation, a KEM is derived from the underlying ML-KEM public key encryption algorithm by deterministically encrypting a random 32-byte message for the public key.  If the random value is weakly-chosen, then an attacker may find it much easier to reproduce the PRNG environment that produced the keys or ciphertext, searching the resulting small set of possibilities for a matching public key or ciphertext value, rather than performing a more complex algorithmic attack against ML-KEM.  The generation of quality random numbers is difficult; see Section 3.3 of {{FIPS203}} for some additional information.
```

pulls.author: danvangeest

comments.author: danvangeest
comments.body: Mohamed's comments: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/spasm/aM0uwTz4pqMXklFMT8UJMfj3hvg/

```suggestion
Mechanism (KEM) Algorithms in the Cryptographic Message Syntax (CMS)” (RFC 9629).
```

Per this part from RFC7322:

>    Similarly, the Abstract should be complete in itself.  It will appear
>    in isolation in publication announcements and in the online index of
>    RFCs.  Therefore, the Abstract must not contain citations.

```suggestion
(*) In the case of AES Key Wrap, a 256-bit key is typically used because AES-192 is not as commonly deployed.
```

```suggestion
| 192-bit           | ML-KEM-768  | 192-bit               | 192-bit (*)                         |
```

```suggestion
{{!RFC9629}} defines the KEMRecipientInfo structure for the use of KEM algorithms for the CMS enveloped-data content type, the CMS authenticated-data content type, and the CMS authenticated-enveloped-data content type. This document specifies the direct use of ML-KEM in the KEMRecipientInfo structure using each of the three parameter sets from {{FIPS203}}, namely MK-KEM-512, ML-KEM-768, and ML-KEM-1024.  It does not address or preclude the use of ML-KEM as part of any hybrid scheme.
```
Just grammar / sentence flow.

I'm not sure how I missed this before, but I don't think this paragraph is accurate.

RFC9629 describes it as:

> ukm is optional user keying material. ... For example, the ukm value could include a nonce, application-specific context information, or an identifier for the originator.

So that can be more than random input, and could have meaningful security benefits for the protocol. For example, you could imagine a "Falko Attack" where an encrypted PDF as mistaken for an encrypted S/MIME. Feeding in some static string into UKM that binds the shared secret to the protocol would prevent that attack.

I suggest this re-wording of the paragraph:

> ukm is an optional additional keying material that binds the shared secret key to some protocol state, for example a nonce, transaction ID, application-specific context information, or an identifier for the originator. Since not all protocols built on top of CMS will make use of the ukm, CMS implementations MAY choose to not support ukm. Implementations that do not support ukm SHOULD by gracefully discontinue processing when the ukm field is present since failure to do so will result in the derivation of different keying material than the sender.

To me, this seems like a trivial part of the spec; it really doesn't save you any effort to implement it, but if we want to make it optional, I think that's the way to do it.
